answers.content_html: Yes, we would both view the motion from the same reference point because both of us are at rest in Earth’s frame of reference.
answers.feedback_html: Even though both are at rest in Earth’s frame of reference, the point from where the motion of the soccer game is observed, is different. For example, if the ball is right in front of one person, then for the other person, the ball will be seen at an angle.

stem_html: What is the difference between distance and displacement?

answers.content_html: Distance has both magnitude and direction, while displacement has magnitude but no direction.
answers.feedback_html: Recall the definition of distances and displacements. Think again which one has direction and magnitude both.

answers.content_html: Distance has magnitude but no direction, while displacement has both magnitude and direction.

answers.feedback_html: It is correct that distances have magnitude only and no direction, but displacement does not only have direction.

stem_html: Can one-dimensional motion have zero distance but a nonzero displacement? What about zero displacement but a nonzero distance?

answers.content_html: One-dimensional motion can have zero distance with a nonzero displacement. Displacement has both magnitude and direction, and it can also have zero displacement with nonzero distance because distance has only magnitude.
answers.feedback_html: Zero distance with nonzero displacement is never possible. Any motion of the object will be a distance the object moves. Zero displacement is possible with nonzero distance as displacement is a vector quantity.

answers.content_html: One-dimensional motion can have zero distance with a nonzero displacement. Displacement has both magnitude and direction, but it cannot have zero displacement with nonzero distance because distance has only magnitude.
answers.feedback_html: Any motion of the object will contribute a nonzero distance. So if an object moves, there will be a nonzero distance covered and any other movement in any direction will get added to this distance. There can be zero displacement with nonzero distance because motion in the opposite direction gets subtracted from the initial displacement.

answers.content_html: One-dimensional motion cannot have zero distance with a nonzero displacement. Displacement has both magnitude and direction, but it can have zero displacement with nonzero distance because distance has only magnitude and any motion will be the distance it moves.
answers.feedback_html: Distance covered will go on increasing with each movement irrespective of the direction in which the object moves, as distance has only magnitude and no direction. Displacement, on the other hand, can decrease if the motion takes place in the opposite direction,because displacement has both magnitude and direction associated with it.
